Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 08:34PM tjany wrote: I believe her grade is a 3 but I would need to confirm with the results in the patho report.  It appears that some oncs in this area are now suggesting TCH using Cytoxan instead of the Carboplatin.  My brother who is an onc at MD Andersen in Houston said Cytoxan and Carboplatin are like comparing apples and oranges.  They are two completely different drugs but he is a prostate onc and not a BC onc so he is differing to the BC oncs because he is not up on the latest in BC treatments.  Just wondering if anyone heard of any other BC oncs suggesting cytoxan with taxotere instead of carboplatin.  Thanks. Regards, TJA
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 04:43PM tjany wrote: Just double checked and it is stage 1 and grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER+, Node negative so I checked the adjuvant web site plugged in the numbers and if I read the output correctly it looks like 10 year survival rates are only increased by around 4-5% with chemo and hormonal therapy.  If this is accurate then maybe no treatment may be an option. Regards, TJA
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: tjany wrote: My wife is 38 years old and was recently diagnosed with Stage 2 Breast cancer, ER+/PR+, HER2+, lymph node neg.  She had a lumpectomy removing a 1.6 cm tumor with clear margins.  She has been to local SW Connecticut hospitals and SK in NY.  They all recommend some form of chemo- ACTH, TCH, etc.  I have found a lot of studies on the web regarding chemo treatments.  Does anyone have any experience and/or studies with a similar diagnoses and the potential risks of choosing to not have chemo?  I cannot seem to find any studies comparing chemo vs. no chemo and associated risk statistics so any input would be greatly appreciated.  She is also considering a double masectomy to try to avoid 5 years of Tamoxifen so I am also looking into the feasibility of this option.  Thanks in advance. Regards, TJA Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2008 06:19AM tjany wrote: I think they refer to the type as invasive ductal.  It has been about 7 weeks since the surgery but we are trying to determine what the risk would be by waiting another 6-8 weeks before starting treatment to allow her to go through an IVF cycle to retrieve eggs.  The bad thing is that an IVF cycle requires high levels of progesterone to be pumped into her to grow as many eggs as possible and with ER+/PR+ cancer this probably cannot be good.  But apart from this it would seem to me (based on absolutely no statistical data but just sort of common sense) that if the cancer has been there for years another few weeks prior to starting treatment would not make a huge difference since we are banking on the treatment being effective in stopping/killing any remaining cancer cells.  The alternative being that if she starts treatment right away and is driven into menopause she will never be able to have children.  Tough decision. Regards, TJA
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 04:04PM tjany wrote: Thanks for the direction.  I passed on the info and I think she is starting to lean towards getting the chemo.  She has gotten recommendations from different oncs for TCH using Cytoxan vs. TCH using Carboplatin.  Does anyone have any experience/info on the pros/cons of one vs. the other.  I could not find a study comparing the two and the oncs cannot seem to agree.  She is pre-menopausal but I am not sure of her tumor grade.  Thanks again in advance. Regards, TJA
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 03:50PM tjany wrote: Is there any risk in waiting a couple of months after surgery before my wife starts treatment?  Some oncologists say you should start treatment within 6 weeks of surgery but I cannot find any statistical basis for this number.  She would like to try another cycle of IVF prior to going into treatment and possibly getting driven into Menopause.  Thanks again. Regards, TJA
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2008 06:58AM tjany wrote: Thanks to everyone for the input.  She started her first chemo treatment of TCH yesterday.  Everything went well. Regards, TJA

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2008 06:02AM tjany wrote: Her oncoscore was 22 which is in that gray area according to the stats.  Wish it was lower like in the low teens then it would make deciding easier.  Thanks. Regards, TJA

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2008 07:56AM tjany wrote: Thanks for all the responses.  We are leaning towards attempting one more IVF cycle and embryo freezing prior to the start of chemo.  Also, based on a lot of info we are also leaning towards TCH instead of the ACTH. Regards, TJA
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to Chemo tjany KathyL

Posts.Content: tjany wrote: My wife started a TCH chemo treatment regiment yesterday.  I have read much information and comments on the pros/cons/risks of ports.  If my wife decides not to have a port put in which the doctors are pushing her for since she is so skinny and has small veins, then will there be any bad long term effects on the recovery of her veins after the treatment has ended?  Thanks. Regards, TJA Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Small Veins and Ports tjany susansblues

Posts.Content: tjany wrote: Hello. My wife is scheduled to start radiation treatment now that she has completed chemo.  The doctor is planning on 33 treatments of 6040 rads with a boost in the last week.  Is this a normal dosage?  Does anyone know how they calculate this dosage?  I have read other people getting only 4500-5000 rads and even less.  I have done a bunch of searches on the web and have not come up with too much viable info.  Any advice would be appreciated.  Thanks in advance.  She is 38 years old, diagnosed with stage 2 IDC, lumpectomy of a 1.6 cm tumor, grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2+, lymph node neg, clear margins.
